posts.name: Arjun Bhatia
posts.cooked:
I have been doing a personal CAD exercise to design a 2018 robot. While looking at successful intake designs, I noticed teams like 254 and 1323 have a ‚Äòfunnel‚Äô feature to their intake, allowing for a more effective touch-own of Power Cubes.

For teams who had these kinds of intakes, I had two questions about your design process:

What angle (shown in the image below) did you go with?

What prototyping process did you use to decide on this angle?

posts.name: Clayton Yocom
posts.cooked: For us this angle was the subject of a lot of prototyping and experimentation. However, one thing to note is that 254/1323‚Äôs intakes also actuate open so the angle here is a bit less critical than ours for instance that was always closed.

posts.name: swami_dm
posts.cooked:
The three cases you need to design for is.

(minimum) approaching a cube normal to a face.

(maximum) approaching a cube with an edge closest to the robot.

Approaching a cube that‚Äôs against the switch wall with the robot bumper also against the switch wall. (18 of the 22 cubes you could grab started in this position)

image 1395√ó755 11.1 KB

image 1395√ó755 11.1 KB

image 1395√ó755 11.1 KB

posts.name: Allison K
posts.cooked:
My memory is a bit fuzzy, but I recall approaching intake design as parameterization.  Rather than choosing a specific angle that worked, we wanted to determine at what angle did a particular design NOT work.  By identifying the extremes we then translated that into design constraints that could be integrated with packaging considerations.  The optimal angle was then found via iteration over the course of the season (there‚Äôs a picture somewhere of the 8 or so sets of intake plates we went through).

It also helped that we identified pretty early on (the day after kickoff I think?) that we wanted to intake cubes at any angle in any orientation, and be able to either eject them in a direction or drop them from above.

Our oversight in prototyping that year was neglecting to consider that the interaction between the intake and cube went differently when either or both of them were on the platform surface or the ramp, so our lesson learned from that year was to include less than optimal arrangements of robots and game pieces in parameterization, and also make sure to test all the surfaces that we‚Äôll encounter on the field.  Also, we only had a wood platform and not the field official material (HDPE?  I don‚Äôt recall what it was) which had a different interaction with the cover that was a bit of a surprise at our first event, so the following season we invested in the field specific material for early prototyping.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: Not exactly the question you‚Äôre asking, but we had only 2 rollers per side which pretty much straight out normally, but we‚Äôre sprung so they could open wider and create a funnel, which worked quite well.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Patrick3357:

‚Ä¶ we had only 2 rollers per side which pretty much straight out normally, but we‚Äôre sprung so they could open wider and create a funnel,

Same here!  Our springs were actually just Vex polycarb square tube. If you‚Äôre interested in dimensions, etc, they‚Äôre down in post #3:

pic: Mini-Koopa, our 2018 off season robot CD-Media: Photos

link_counts.title: pic: Mini-Koopa, our 2018 off season robot

posts.name: Crystal
posts.cooked:
For my team, the front wheel width was less about some sort of performance / grip advantage, and more about widening the effective area in which the robot could grab game pieces. I suspect that is what you‚Äôre seeing in these west coast intakes as well - my memory is that they used smaller wheels for packaging and to fit more contact points into the mechanism, so they made the outermost wheel wider to increase the intake‚Äôs range. The overall width seemed to be determined based on what would fit through their elevators.

Compliance in your intake and/or wheels should account for all cube orientations. I‚Äôd definitely recommend having some sort of system to ‚Äúsolve‚Äù diagonal cubes on the fly, which can be as simple as a passive curved piece of plastic at the back of the intake, or as complex as current monitoring on the intake wheels.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
Can I suggest that the funnel was not the best 2018 intake design?  We found that a single pair of wheels worked better, and did not depend on which way the cube was oriented (one side was shorter than the other).

The secret was that the ‚Äúclaw‚Äù holding the wheels was held ‚Äúsoft closed‚Äù by a reduced air pressure cylinder, such that it would open up as the wheels intaked the sides and corners of the cube.  Since we used the same claw for lifting the cube, we used a separate solenoid valve to increase the pressure for a ‚Äúhard grip‚Äù.

https://youtu.be/Coh4LwNu2Yc?t=27

posts.name: Nate Laverdure (he/him)
posts.cooked:
It‚Äôs 2018.

You‚Äôre asked to intake boxes from the floor.

You scale from a 2015 design that works!

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked: I don‚Äôt think this was reflected in the reality of on field performance.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: I disagree.  Our robot intake outperformed most IMO.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
Outperforming most wasn‚Äôt your original claim.

Did it outperform the best angled intakes?

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: We‚Äôd have to do a lot of video analysis to confirm.  I‚Äôm willing to be proven wrong, but yes that‚Äôs my impression.  At minimum, our intake did not have to waste time righting tipped-over cubes, which as I understand it is something most of the ‚Äúfunnel‚Äù intakes (with fixed wheel spacing) had to do.

posts.name: Kaleb Dodd
posts.cooked: Yeah I think the main argument would be that they were so good at normal cubes that it made up for that.

posts.name: Michael Cameron
posts.cooked:
This is true. The meme was made before we headed to Houston - as kind of a retort to the obvious design convergence that year. The real takeaway is to not be afraid to try really different things. This intake would happily consume a cube in any orientation. But, like many other designs, it  needed many iterations and tweaks to work well.

Oh yeah. I‚Äôd be remiss if I didn‚Äôt repost this classic:

My favorite fact about that robot is that you guys used 11 full CIMs on it.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: The spinning flaps are what makes 5818 so iconic. I was deeply saddened upon discovering that your 2022 robot did not feature them. Michael, you would make me the happiest man in the world if you all brought the flaps back for 2023. #flapbacktoreality
